title: My Weirdly Great Experience with the Pear Tallow Balm
body:
Okay so. I was sitting there, right? It was like 10 PM on a Tuesday, maybe a Wednesday. My hands were a disaster. Like, cracking by the knuckles, the whole winter thing. I’d tried that fancy lotion in the blue bottle, the one that costs twenty bucks and smells like a hospital. Nothing. My skin just drank it and asked for more. I was scrolling, half-watching some baking show, and I saw this thing. A tallow balm. Beef fat. For your skin. I remember thinking, “That’s… a choice.” But my hands hurt. And the jar looked cute. So I clicked it. The one that said “Pear.” I figured if I was gonna smear cow fat on myself, it should at least try to smell nice.

I didn’t expect much. Honestly. It arrived in this little box, the kind you get from Etsy shops where you can tell someone packed it carefully. There was a coffee ring on my desk from that morning. I opened it. The jar’s cold. You know how glass gets. I unscrewed it.

And it didn’t smell like beef. Thank god. It smelled like… a pear. But not a candy pear. Not like a Jolly Rancher. More like if you had a really ripe pear sitting in a bowl in a sunny kitchen, and you walked by and got just a whiff of it. That’s it. No perfume cloud. Just a quiet, fruity thing. It was a relief. The texture threw me though. Thick. Like really thick. Like cold butter thick. I scooped a tiny bit with my finger and just stared at it for a second. “Here goes nothing,” I thought. Rubbed it between my palms.

It melted. Not like water, but like… it just became oil. Warm oil. I put it on my hands, over those cracked spots. It felt heavy for like, three seconds. Then it was just gone. Absorbed. My skin looked… calm. Not shiny. Not greasy. Just skin. But softer. The tight, itchy feeling was gone. Just gone. I sat there wiggling my fingers, feeling the weird absence of discomfort. Huh. So that’s a tallow balm. A pear tallow balm, I guess. I was intrigued.

## How Beef Tallow Ended Up on My Face

Look, I get it. It sounds insane. Beef tallow skincare? Really? I had the same reaction. I’m not a homesteader. I buy my groceries at the regular store. But I kept using it on my hands for a week. The cracks healed. Actually healed. Not just covered up. So I got curious. I read a bit. Apparently, this stuff—grass-fed beef tallow—is weirdly close to the oils our own skin makes. Our sebum. So it’s like your skin recognizes it. It doesn’t just sit on top; it goes in and says, “Hey, I’m here to help.” The one I got is whipped, which I think just means they mix air into it so it’s not a brick. And it’s made in France, which feels fancy for cow fat.

My face was next. I have skin that can’t decide if it’s dry or sensitive. Winter turns it into a flaky, red mess. I was using this expensive cream that came in a gold jar. It did nothing except make my bank account sad. One night, after a shower, my face felt like parchment. I looked at the tallow balm. “Why not,” I muttered. I took an even tinier amount. Like half a pea. Pressed it between my fingers to warm it up, then just… patted it on. Over my damp skin.

Same thing. That heavy-for-a-second feeling, then it just sank in. No residue. No pillow stickiness. I woke up the next morning and my face wasn’t tight. It didn’t have that angry, stretched feeling. It just felt normal. Neutral. I started doing it every night. It became the last step. After whatever serum, after whatever—just a tiny bit of this pear tallow balm to lock it all in. My routine got simpler. Because this one thing actually did the job.

## What This Pear Scent Actually Does (And Doesn't Do)

The scent is the whole reason I’m writing this, really. If it smelled like nothing, or worse, like fried food, I probably wouldn’t have kept using it. The pear thing is subtle. It’s not a fragrance, you know? It doesn’t announce itself. It’s just there when you open the jar. A gentle, fresh, fruity smell. It’s not sophisticated. That’s a word for perfumes. It’s just… pleasant. Nice. It makes the whole experience feel less clinical and more like a small, nice thing you do for yourself.

I use it at night mostly. Sometimes in the morning if it’s brutally cold. The ritual is simple. Cold jar. Scoop. The smell hits you—that quiet pear note. Warm it between your fingers. Apply. Done. It’s not a spa day. It’s a thirty-second thing. But that little scent makes it enjoyable. It’s a sensory cue that says “okay, day is over, time to fix the damage.” It doesn’t linger on your skin, which I like. I don’t want to smell like fruit all night. I just want the process to be inoffensive. And it is. It’s more than inoffensive. It’s actually nice.

It’s hydrating, yeah. But all tallow balms are probably hydrating. This one just doesn’t make you feel like you’re rubbing a steak on your face while you do it. The scent makes it feel considered. Like someone knew that for this to work in the real world, for normal people, it had to be approachable. A natural pear skincare thing, not a weird survivalist thing. That’s the difference.

## My Skin Now & The Weird Part

So I’ve been using it for… a month? Maybe six weeks. I’m bad with time. I’m on my second jar now, which says something because I never finish skincare products. I get bored. The weird part is the lack of drama. My skin isn’t “glowing.” It’s not “radiant.” Those are magazine words. It’s just… okay. It’s not dry. It’s not flaky. It doesn’t get that wind-burned feeling when I come inside. It’s stable. Boring, even. And after years of my face being a high-maintenance problem, boring is fantastic.

My elbows are smooth. I didn’t even target my elbows. I just had extra balm on my hands sometimes and would rub it there. They haven’t been this smooth since I was a kid, I swear. And my lips! I used it on my chapped lips once in desperation. Works better than any waxy lip balm I’ve ever bought. It just fixes the problem instead of masking it.

I told my mom about it. She’s in her 60s and her skin gets painfully dry in winter. I was like, “Mom, I know this sounds nuts, but get the pear one.” She was skeptical. She called me last week. “What was that stuff you sent me? My hands are better.” That felt like a win. It’s one thing to trick yourself into thinking something works. It’s another when your skeptical mother admits it.

I got mine from this little Etsy shop. I won’t name it because this isn’t an ad, but you can find it. There are a few that make it. Just look for the whipped kind, grass-fed. And if you’re scent-sensitive, maybe get unscented. But for me, the pear scented tallow balm is the one. It’s the reason the product went from a weird experiment to a regular on my shelf.

## Quick Questions I Get Asked

**Is beef tallow good for your face?**
Yeah, weirdly. From what I understand, its fat profile is super similar to our skin’s natural oils. So it absorbs deeply and helps reinforce your skin barrier instead of just coating it. My face seems to think it’s good, anyway.

**Does tallow balm clog pores?**
Hasn’t for me. And I’m prone to clogged pores. It’s non-comedogenic, which means it shouldn’t. It absorbs so completely that there’s nothing left on the surface to clog anything. It feels cleaner than some “oil-free” gels I’ve used.

**What does the pear tallow balm smell like?**
It’s light. Like a fresh, ripe pear, not a sugary candy. You smell it when you open the jar, but it doesn’t stick around on your skin. It just makes using it a nicer experience. It’s a gentle, fruity scent.

Anyway. If your skin is throwing a fit this winter and nothing in a plastic bottle is helping, this might be worth a shot. The whole beef tallow thing is strange until you try it. And then it’s just… logic. It just works. I’m probably gonna order another jar soon. My first one’s almost gone.
